questions.text: A 3-year-old child with short bowel syndrome presents with severe malabsorption. Which surgical procedure involves stapling a dilated bowel into V shapes on alternating sides, decreasing the width and increasing the bowel length to improve nutrient absorption?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) STEP procedure

 

Explanation:

  • The Serial Transverse Enteroplasty (STEP) is a minimal dissection procedure that narrows the lumen of the dilated small intestine by stapling it transversely, effectively increasing its length.
  • This technique allows food to travel in a zig-zag pattern, enhancing tolerance to enteral feeding and promoting significant catch-up growth.

Bianchi procedure (Option A) involves the split of the small intestine into two parallel segments, and the ends are approximated. 

Whipple Procedure ( Pancreaticoduodenectomy) (Option B) involves the removal of the pancreatic head, duodenum, distal stomach, gallbladder, and distal bile duct. 

Billroth I and II Procedures (Option C) are types of gastrectomies.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child with a history of extensive small bowel resection due to necrotizing enterocolitis is diagnosed with short bowel syndrome. Which among the following surgical procedures can help increase the bowel length and potentially reduce the dependency on parenteral nutrition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bianchi procedure

 

Explanation:

  • The Bianchi procedure/ Longitudinal intestinal lengthening and tailoring (LILT) is recognised as an effective surgical treatment for short bowel syndrome (SBS).
  • Bianchi initially described the procedure for intestinal lengthening where the mesenteric vascular bed is divided into two systems.
  • The enlarged small intestine is split into two parallel segments, each with its own blood supply, and then reconnected.
  • This technique reduces the small intestine's diameter by 50% and doubles its length.

 

Whipple Procedure ( Pancreaticoduodenectomy), Billroth I and II procedures and Ileostomy (Option B, C and D) don't involve intestinal lengthening

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with severe malnutrition and liver dysfunction even after subclavian parenteral nutrition for extensive small bowel resection. Which of the following is the most definitive treatment for his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Small bowel transplantation

 

Explanation:

  • Small bowel transplantation is the definitive treatment for severe malnutrition and liver dysfunction after extensive small bowel resection when parenteral nutrition is insufficient.

 

Treatment of Short bowel syndrome:

Medical/ supportive:

  • Total parenteral nutrition ( Subclavian preferred over jugular) (Option A ruled out) and long-term home parenteral nutrition.
  • Diarrhea: loperamide/codeine phosphate.
  • To bind bile salts: Oral cholestyramine
  • To reduce secretions from the stomach, liver and pancreas: H2 antagonists/PPls/somatostatin.
  • Octreotide: reduces the secretion and reduces GI motility.
  • Fluid and electrolyte management.

 

Surgical management:

  • Principle: To delay the intestinal transit time and increase the absorption surface.
  • Small bowel transplantation is the ideal. (Option B)
  • Intestinal lengthening procedures: Binachi's surgery, serial transverse enteroplasty (STEP). These procedures are not definitive. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient who underwent extensive resection of the small intestine for Crohn’s disease presents with persistent diarrhea and worsening malnutrition. Despite following a strict dietary regimen, he is unable to maintain adequate nutritional status or fluid balance without intravenous support. What is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Parenteral nutrition

 

Explanation:

  • Parenteral nutrition is the appropriate management strategy for patients with short bowel syndrome who cannot maintain nutritional and fluid balance through oral or enteral means.
  • This approach provides essential nutrients directly into the bloodstream.

Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) :

  • Intravenous administration of nutrients (carbohydrates, proteins, fats, vitamins, minerals),for patients unable to maintain nutrition through oral intake alone

Intestinal Failure is the inability to maintain satisfactory fluid, electrolyte, or nutritional homeostasis without intravenous support, therefore rendering oral rehydration and enteral nutrition insufficient. This is due to poor absorption (Options A & B ruled out)

Antidiarrheal medications (Option D): These may alleviate diarrhea symptoms but do not resolve the underlying issue of inadequate nutrient and fluid absorption.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with a history of extensive small bowel resection presents with persistent diarrhea, significant weight loss, and signs of malnutrition. She is unable to maintain adequate fluid and nutritional balance despite dietary modifications. what condition is she most likely experiencing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Short bowel syndrome

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical features of persistent diarrhea, significant weight loss, and malnutrition, along with difficulty maintaining fluid and nutritional balance, are indicative of short bowel syndrome, especially following extensive small bowel resection.

 

Short Bowel Syndrome (SBS):

  • Clinical Features:
    • Intractable diarrhea
    • Impaired nutrient absorption
    • Progressive malnutrition
  • Cause: Resection or bypass of the small intestine
  • Intestinal Failure:
    • Inability to maintain satisfactory fluid, electrolyte, or nutritional homeostasis without intravenous support, therefore rendering oral rehydration and enteral nutrition insufficient.
    • This is due to poor absorption.
  • Treatment: Parenteral nutrition

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with radiation enteritis undergoes bowel resection and develops short bowel syndrome. Which statement about bowel function is correct?

choices.text: The jejunum compensates well for the loss of the ileum.
The ileum can compensate for a resected jejunum due to better absorption.
Short bowel syndrome is less severe with distal bowel loss.
The ileum’s compensation is reduced due to looser junctions.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The ileum can compensate for a resected jejunum due to better absorption.

 

Explanation:

  • The ileum, with its tighter intercellular junctions and superior fluid absorptive capacity. (Option D ruled out)
  • Ileum can compensate for the loss of the jejunum, making it capable of taking over some of the jejunal functions.
  • But ejunum cannot compensate for a missing ileum. (Option A ruled out)
  • Therefore, jejunal resections are better tolerated because of the adaptability of ileum.
  • Short bowel syndrome usually affect the distal small intestine more than the proximal and distal bowel loss results in a more severe form of SBS. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with complaints of fatigue, shortness of breath, and swelling in his legs. He has had a history of intermittent facial flushing and diarrhea for the past several years. Physical examination reveals a new heart murmur. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Carcinoid heart disease

 

Explanation:

  • The patient's history of facial flushing, diarrhea, and a newly detected heart murmur, coupled with symptoms of right-sided heart failure (such as leg swelling and shortness of breath), strongly points toward carcinoid heart disease.
  • Carcinoid heart disease is a complication of carcinoid syndrome, which results from the release of serotonin and other vasoactive substances by a carcinoid tumor.

Pathophysiology:

  • Plaque-like deposits composed of smooth muscle cells, myofibroblasts, extracellular matrix and an overlying endothelial layer which lead to valve dysfunction.
  • Valvular dysfunction can lead to edema, ascites and right-sided heart failure.
  • Pulmonary heart disease primarily affects the right side of the heart.
  • Within the right heart, the tricuspid valve is the first to be affected, followed by the pulmonary valve.
  • Regurgitant lesions are more common than stenotic lesions.

questions.text: Which of the following diagnostic steps is most appropriate to establish a definitive diagnosis of abdominal TB in this patient?

choices.text: Biopsy of the involved site with mycobacterial culture and nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT)

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Biopsy of the involved site with mycobacterial culture and nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT)

 

Explanation:

  • Biopsy of involved site with mycobacterial culture and nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT):
    • It’s the most definitive method for diagnosing abdominal TB, and allows for the direct demonstration of M. tuberculosis in tissue or fluid samples, providing conclusive evidence of the infection.
       

Diagnostic Method

Details

Definitive Diagnosis (Option D)

M. tuberculosis Demonstration:

  • Peritoneal fluid (in ascites)
  • Biopsy specimen (peritoneum, intestine, liver)
  • Mycobacterial culture and/or NAAT:
  • Histopathology: The presence of caseating granulomas suggests TB but is not pathognomonic

Radiographic Imaging

CT with Enterography Protocol: (Option B ruled out)

Preferred for cross-sectional evaluation

  • Intestinal TB: Concentric mural thickening in the ileocecal region, lymphadenopathy with hypodense centers
  • Peritoneal TB: Ascites, lymph nodes, mesentery and omental thickening, peritoneal thickening
  • Hepatic TB:
    • Miliary disease: Multiple low-density micronodules throughout the liver
    • Local disease: Large solitary nodule or 2-3 low-density nodules with calcification and peripheral enhancement

Ultrasound:

Detects lymphadenopathy, ascites, peritoneal thickening, omental thickening, bowel wall thickening

Other Imaging:

  • Small bowel follow-through/barium enema: Mucosal ulcerations, strictures, deformed cecum, incompetent ileocecal valve
  • Plain radiography: Air fluid levels, dilated small bowel loops, hepatic calcifications
  • Chest radiography: For suspected abdominal TB

Ascitic Fluid Analysis

Routine Tests:

  • Cell count and differential, albumin and protein concentration, Gram stain

TB-specific Tests:

  • ADA level (Option C ruled out), AFB smear, mycobacterial culture, NAAT for M. tuberculosis (if available)

Typical Findings:

  • Lymphocytic ascites with SAAG <1.1 g/dL in noncirrhotic patients (Option A ruled out)
  • Straw-colored ascites
  • leukocyte count 150-4000 cells/mm³
  • relative lymphocytic pleocytosis
  • Protein content >3.0 g/dL

The sensitivity of AFB smear and mycobacterial culture is low

Biopsy Specimens

  
  • Laparoscopy: Visualization of peritoneum, peritoneal biopsy
  • Endoscopy: Biopsies in the setting of intestinal involvement
  • Radiographic-guided interventions
  • Histopathology:
    • Caseating granulomas and positive acid-fast stain in fewer than 33% of cases
    • Confluent granulomas, granulomas >400 micrometres, >5 granulomas in one segment, and submucosal granulomas suggest TB enteritis

Additional Diagnostic Tools
  • Tuberculin skin test/interferon-gamma release assay: Positive in abdominal TB but limited value (does not differentiate active disease from latent infection)
  • Stool PCR: Useful adjunctive tool for diagnosing intestinal TB

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with sudden onset severe abdominal pain that started 30 minutes after his last meal. He is tachycardic and hypotensive and laboratory investigations reveal leukocytosis and elevated chromogranin A levels. A CT scan shows bowel wall enhancement and free fluid in the abdomen. Which of the following is the most preferred treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Segmental resection + En-bloc lymphadenectomy

 

Explanation:

  • This patient with sudden onset abdominal pain and elevated levels of chromogranin A is a case of a small bowel carcinoid tumor.
  • The most preferred treatment option is surgical exploration with segmental bowel resection with en-block lymphadenectomy.

Management:

  • The preferred treatment approach is segmental resection combined with en-bloc lymphadenectomy. (Option A)
  • Total bowel resection is a highly aggressive approach that is generally avoided unless necessary.
    • Intestinal resection should be limited as carcinoid patients will do poorly if a short bowel syndrome results. (Option D ruled out)
  • Somatostatin analogue therapy has antiproliferative effects and is used in unresectable or metastatic disease. (Option C ruled out)
  • Chemotherapy Regimen (preferred if surgery is not possible) (Option B ruled out)
    • D – Dacarbazine
    • E – Epirubicin
    • F5 – Fluorouracil

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents with episodes of flushing, diarrhea, and abdominal pain over the past six months. She also reports intermittent wheezing and feels her symptoms worsen after consuming certain foods. On physical examination, she exhibits a rash on her face and neck. Imaging studies reveal a tumor in the ileum of the small intestine. What is the initial investigation of choice for localisation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy (SRS)

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario is suggestive of a carcinoid tumor.
  • Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy (SRS) is used as the initial investigation for localization as it is the most sensitive test for diagnosing carcinoid syndrome .
  • The extent of disease can be assessed preoperatively using octreotide scanning i.e somatostatin receptor scintigraphy , which may detect the tumor.

 

Investigations

  • Urinary detention of 5-HIAA is used to detect Carcinoid tumor .It is the investigation of choice  but SRS is the initial investigation (Option C ruled  out )
  • The most effective investigation for precise localization is DOPA–PET. (Option B ruled out)
  • Triple phase contrast-enhanced CT scan is most commonly used as it is widely available but CT scan sensitivity is low (50%) and not the initial investigation of choice (Option A ruled out).

questions.text: What is the most peculiar feature of gastric carcinoid tumor?

choices.text: Bright red patchy flushing of skin

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Bright red patchy flushing of skin

 

Explanation:

  • Bright red patchy flushing of skin is a peculiar feature of the bowel carcinoid tumor due to the excessive production of vasoactive peptides, primarily serotonin.

 

Clinical features:

  • Reddish-blue cyanosis, facial and upper chest flushing attacks, diarrhoea, asthmatic attacks (bronchospasm) and tricuspid regurgitation. (Option D)
  • Abdominal pain, bowel obstruction and abdominal distension are non-specific and not peculiar features of bowel carcinoid tumors.(Option A, B, C)

questions.text: A 55 y/o male presents with flushing, diarrhea, and recurrent episodes of bronchospasm. Imaging reveals multiple masses in the ileum. Laboratory tests show elevated serotonin levels. What is the most likely type of tumor responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Midgut Carcinoid Tumor

 

Explanation:

  • Midgut carcinoid tumors develop in the jejunum, ileum, appendix, or right colon and are known for their high secretion of serotonin.
  • This hormone is responsible for the symptoms of carcinoid syndrome, such as flushing, diarrhea, and bronchospasm.
  • The presence of multiple masses in the ileum and elevated serotonin levels strongly suggest a midgut carcinoid tumor as the underlying cause.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: The most common small bowel tumor in adults is carcinoid tumor.
The most common small bowel tumor in children is a neuroendocrine tumor.
The most common primary malignant small bowel tumor is adenocarcinoma.
The most common small bowel tumor in adults is lymphoma.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The most common primary malignant small bowel tumor is adenocarcinoma.

 

Explanation:

  • Adenocarcinoma is the most frequently occurring malignant small bowel tumor.
     

Classification of Small Bowel Tumors

Benign Tumors
  • Adenomas: Most common benign SBT is adenoma
  • Lipomas
  • Haemangiomas
  • Neurogenic tumors

Malignant Tumors

Adenocarcinoma (Option C)

 

  • The most common primary malignant SBT is: Adenocarcinoma > Carcinoid>Lymphoma and (Option A ruled out)

Neuroendocrine Tumors (NETs)

Arise from Kulchitsky cells, small primary tumor with potential for significant lymph node metastases, up to one-third involve multiple tumors.

Lymphomas

 

  • The most common SBT in children is Lymphoma. (Option B and D ruled out)

Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumors (GISTs)
  • Mesenchymal tumors, are difficult to classify as benign or malignant, with larger size and high c-kit (CD117) staining associated with malignancy.

questions.text: A 65 y/o male presents with chronic abdominal discomfort and bloating. Imaging shows multiple jejunal diverticula. The physician suspects these are due to increased intraluminal pressure. What is the most likely etiology of these diverticula?

choices.text: Congenital origin due to incomplete recanalization of the duodenum
Acquired origin due to smooth muscle motor dysfunction
Protrusion of the entire intestinal wall layers

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Acquired origin due to smooth muscle motor dysfunction

 

Explanation:

  • Jejunal diverticula are acquired in origin.
  • They are false diverticula, meaning they involve herniation of the mucosa and submucosa through the muscular layer of the intestine.
  • They result from a motor dysfunction of the smooth muscle or the myenteric plexus.
  • This dysfunction causes abnormal contractions of the small bowel, leading to increased pressure inside the lumen and subsequent herniation of the mucosal and submucosal layers through the weakest parts of the bowel wall.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient with gastrointestinal tuberculosis presents with abdominal pain and intermittent diarrhea. Imaging studies reveal a long, narrow filling defect in the terminal ileum. What is the most likely diagnosis based on these findings?

choices.text: Ulcerative tuberculosis with subacute obstruction and perforation
Crohn’s disease with a narrowed segment and proximal distension
Hyperplastic tuberculosis with a filling defect in the terminal ileum and lymphadenopathy
Appendicitis with mass in the right iliac fossa

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hyperplastic tuberculosis with a filling defect in the terminal ileum and lymphadenopathy

 

Explanation:

  • Hyperplastic tuberculosis often presents with a long, narrow filling defect in the terminal ileum on imaging, and it is associated with lymphadenopathy.
  • This lines with the patient's presentation and imaging findings.

 

Feature

Hyperplastic Tuberculosis

 

Symptoms
  • Abdominal pain
  • Intermittent diarrhea

Complications/Consequences
  • Incomplete ileal obstruction
  • Stasis
  • Bacterial overgrowth
  • Steatorrhea
  • Anemia
  • Weight loss

Diagnostic Findings
  • Physical exam: Mass in right iliac fossa
  • Barium follow-through/small bowel enema: Long, narrow filling defect in terminal ileum
  • CT scan: Narrowed segment with proximal distension and lymphadenopathy

questions.text: A patient with pulmonary tuberculosis is diagnosed with ulcers in the terminal ileum. Which form of gastrointestinal tuberculosis is characterized by this presentation?

choices.text: Hyperplastic tuberculosis with intestinal wall thickening.
Ulcerative tuberculosis with transverse ulcers and serosal thickening.
Crohn’s disease with abscesses and fistulas.
Hyperplastic tuberculosis with abscesses and fistulas.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ulcerative tuberculosis with transverse ulcers and serosal thickening.

 

Explanation:

  • Ulcerative tuberculosis is characterized by multiple transverse ulcers in the terminal ileum and the thickening of the serosa.

Pathological Variants of GI Tuberculosis:

Variant

Description

Ulcerative Tuberculosis (Option B)
  • Caused by ingestion of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, often in those with pulmonary TB.
  • Results in multiple transverse ulcers, primarily in the terminal ileum.
  • Leads to thickening and inflammation of the serosa, covered in tubercles.

Hyperplastic Tuberculosis

(Option A ruled out)
  • Develops in individuals with high resistance to Mycobacterium tuberculosis who ingest the bacteria.
  • Commonly affects the ileocaecal region and distal ileum.
  • Causes chronic inflammation in lymphoid follicles, thickening of the intestinal wall, and narrowing of the lumen.
  • Less likely to cause abscesses and fistulas, and often presents with regional lymph node involvement with potential caseation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with symptoms of abdominal pain and weight loss. He has a history of pulmonary tuberculosis. On examination, his abdomen is tender in the right iliac fossa. A barium follow-through study reveals a long, narrow filling defect in the terminal ileum. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hyperplastic tuberculosis

 

Explanation:

  • Hyperplastic Tuberculosis is characterized by ingestion of Mycobacterium tuberculosis in high-resistance individuals, affecting the ileocaecal region and distal ileum.
  • It causes chronic inflammation, thickening of the intestinal wall, and lumen narrowing, which match the findings in the question.

Etiopathogenesis of Gastrointestinal Tuberculosis (GI TB)

 

Hyperplastic Tuberculosis 

 

Cause

Ingestion of Mycobacterium tuberculosis by individuals with high resistance.

Affected Area

The ileocaecal region; can also affect the distal ileum

Characteristics
  • Chronic inflammation in lymphoid follicles.
  • Thickening of the intestinal wall and lumen narrowing.
  • Rare abscess and fistula formation.
  • Early involvement of regional lymph nodes, which may caseate

Barium follow-through and CT
  • Long narrow filling defect
  • CT shows a narrowed segment with proximal distension

questions.text: A 25-year-old female with a history of weight loss presents with intermittent abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Imaging shows compression of the third portion of the duodenum between the aorta and the superior mesenteric artery. Conservative dietary management has failed. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Laparoscopic duodenojejunostomy

 

Explanation:

  • Laparoscopic duodenojejunostomy is the preferred surgical option for treating superior mesenteric artery syndrome after conservative management has failed due to its minimally invasive approach.

Superior Mesenteric Artery (SMA) Syndrome:

  • Description: This rare condition is characterized by compression of the third portion of the duodenum between the aorta and the superior mesenteric artery.
  • Symptoms: This leads to proximal small bowel obstruction, especially in individuals with significant weight loss or other risk factors.

Surgical Treatments for SMA Syndrome

Treatment Type

Description

Strong Procedure

Duodenum is mobilized by dividing the ligament of Treitz. Once the duodenal jejunal junction is mobilized, the duodenum is positioned to the right of the superior mesenteric artery

Laparoscopic Duodenojejunostomy (Option A)

Optimal definitive treatment; involves creating a bypass from the duodenum to the jejunum.

Open Surgical Procedures (Option B & D ruled out)

Employed when laparoscopic methods are not feasible or have failed.

Other Interventions

Conservative management (dietary modifications, nutritional support) is attempted first but often fails. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 30 y/o male with a history of rapid weight loss presents with severe postprandial abdominal pain and vomiting. The physician suspects Superior Mesenteric Artery (SMA) syndrome. Which imaging technique is most suitable for visualizing the compression of the duodenum by the SMA and accurately measuring the aortomesenteric angle?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Computed Tomography (CT) Scan

 

Explanation:

  • A CT scan is the preferred diagnostic tool for SMA syndrome.
  • A computed tomography (CT) offers detailed visualization of the duodenum, SMA, and aorta.
  • It enables precise measurement of the aortomesenteric angle and distance, which are critical for confirming the diagnosis.
  • Additionally, it can detect associated complications, such as acute pancreatitis or gastric necrosis, making it the most comprehensive method.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT TRUE regarding superior mesenteric artery syndrome?

choices.text: Early satiety and postprandial epigastric pain are present.
The knee to the chest or left lateral decubitus position alleviates symptoms.
Presentation is always acute, needing emergency intervention.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Presentation is always acute, needing emergency intervention.


 

Explanation:

  • Depending on the severity of the duodenal obstruction, pain can be intermittent to constant.

 

Clinical manifestations of SMA syndrome:

  • The most common symptoms are epigastric pain, nausea, and vomiting.
  • Others: abdominal distension, weight loss, early satiety and postprandial epigastric pain which worsens in the supine position. (Option A ruled out)
  • Pain can be intermittent or constant depending on the severity.
  • Alleviating factors: Increasing the angle which can be demonstrated in a prone, knee to the chest, or left lateral decubitus position. (Option B ruled out)
  • Can present as acute or chronic. (Option C)
    • In the acute phase: Severe intestinal obstruction can be life-threatening.
    • In the chronic state: Intermittent postprandial pain, nausea, vomiting, and weight loss, thus worsening the syndrome.

questions.text: Which part of the duodenum is compressed in superior mesenteric artery syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Third

 

Explanation:

  • Superior mesenteric artery syndrome or Wilkie syndrome, or Cast syndrome is characterized by compression of the third portion of the duodenum by the artery as it passes over the third part of the duodenum.
  • Rare cause of proximal small bowel obstruction.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is diagnosed with symptomatic Meckel's diverticulum after presenting with painless rectal bleeding. The diverticulum is found to be inflamed and with ulcers in the base. Which of the following surgical procedures is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Resection of small bowel with diverticulum.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Resection of small bowel with diverticulum resection.

 

Explanation:

  • If the base of the diverticulum is unhealthy (indurated, ulcerated), it is safer to perform limited small bowel resection of the involved segment, followed by anastomosis.

 

Treatment of Meckel’s diverticulum:

  1. Healthy base (no induration or ulceration): Diverculectomy (excision of the diverticulum only) + anastomosis. (Option D ruled out)
  2. Unhealthy base (ulceration, presence of gastric mucosa): Resection of the small bowel with the diverticulum + anastomosis. (Option B)
  3. Incidentally detected during an elective surgery: Diverculectomy is performed as it has an increased risk of complications (12% risk if left untreated).

(a-c) The umbilicus is divided vertically to create a pair of laterally based skin flaps. The subcutaneous tissue is cored out from the anterior abdominal wall through the umbilical incision. (d) A fibrous cord connected to a Meckel diverticulum and a urachal remnant (white arrow) is seen. (e) The blood vessel supplying the Meckel diverticulum is divided and ligated. (f and g) Limited segmental resection including the Meckel diverticulum and the fistula is completed. The cut edge is closed using absorbable sutures

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with intermittent episodes of blood in his stools without pain. On examination, there are no signs of acute abdomen. Blood investigations reveal he is anemic. Which is the investigation of choice in this case for Meckel's diverticulum?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Tc-pertechnetate scan
 

Explanation:

  • 99mTc-pertechnetate scan is the investigation of choice for Meckel’s diverticulum in the presence of gastric mucosa which is suspected due to painless bleeding in this case scenario.

 

Investigations in Meckel’s diverticulum:

  • 99mTc-pertechnetate scan: Absorbed by the ectopic gastric mucosa, allowing for visualization. Sensitivity is 85%, specificity is 95%, and an accuracy of 90% in the pediatric age group. (Option C)
  • Plain abdominal radiography, CT abdomen (Option D ruled out), and ultrasonography (Option A ruled out) are seldom useful.
  • Endoscopy: (Option B ruled out) Helpful in false-negative cases, but not the investigation of choice.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents with painless rectal bleeding. CT scans show a diverticulum 2 inches long located around 2 feet proximal to the ileocaecal valve. A Technetium-99m pertechnetate scan shows an area of increased uptake in the right lower quadrant. What is the most likely type of ectopic mucosal tissue found in the diverticulum that can explain these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Gastric

 

Explanation:

  • In this scenario, the boy is most likely to be having Meckel's diverticulum and ulcers are formed in the surrounding area due to acid secreted from the ectopic gastric mucosa in Meckel’s diverticulum, which causes bleeding.
  • The 99mTc-pertechnetate scan helps in the visualization of the ectopic gastric mucosa.
  • Most common ectopic mucosa in Meckel’s diverticulum is Gastric (Option A) > Pancreatic > Colonic

 

Rule of 2 in Meckel’s diverticulum:

  • Seen in 2% of the population.
  • Usually, the length is 2 inches
  • Location: 2 feet proximal to the ileocecal junction.
  • Diameter: 2 cm.
  • Mostly symptomatic in children <2 years of age.

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics is true regarding Meckel's diverticulum?

choices.text: Located approximately 30 cm from the ileocecal valve.
Always lined with ectopic pancreatic tissue
Arises from the mesenteric border of the ileum.
Contains all the layers of the bowel wall.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Contains all the layers of the bowel wall.

 

Explanation:

Meckel's diverticulum contains all three coats of the bowel wall and has its own blood supply.

 

Anatomy of Meckel's diverticulum:

 

  • Embryology: Persistent remnant of the Vitello-intestinal duct or omphalomesenteric duct.
  • Location: Antimesenteric side of the ileum (Option C ruled out), approximately 60 cm from the ileocaecal valve. (Option A ruled out)
  • Size: 5 cm long.
  • It contains all three coats of the bowel wall and has its own blood supply. (Option D)
  • Lined by pluripotent cells.
  • Most commonly lined by gastric mucosa (50%).
  • Pancreatic mucosa only in 5% of cases. (Option B ruled out)
